is a story event in the Flower Knight Expansion rule book.

Event Text.
Nominate a survivor that can consume to be the host. If that's not possible, the flowers withers and this event ends. The host presses the Virus Flower to their mouth, its delicate petals changing color to match their flesh. A cozy and inspired warmth fills their being as they gently push the flower by its stem down their throat.

Down their Throat.
roll 1d10

If you rolled a 2, 3, 4 or 5, and if the settlement chose the Graves Death Principle, the host builds a small grave and tearfully bids farewell. Nominate a survivor with the least hunt XP. They are moved and gain the Swordsman's Promise secret fighting art. Then, welcome the guest. 

If you rolled a 6, 7, 8 or 9, and if the settlement has innovated Sculpture, the host creates a grand throne from debris and trash. Completing it, they announce "One day, the King will come to claim this." The message sends a ripple of dread through the settlement. Departing survivors gain +5 insanity and a random fighting art. Then, welcome the guest.

Welcome the Guest.
As the flower is digested, a virus enters the host's blood stream and travels to their brain. The host experiences a state of euphoria, as viral genomes are injected into the cells of their prefrontal cortex and pallum.

The host feels as if a satisfying itch within their skull has finally been scratched. That sensation is the last thing they experience as their original self.

The host's brain is newborn, replacing the sum of their life with that of the Guest's.

The host loses all fighting arts, disorders, abilities and impairments. Then, they gain all the Guest's fighting arts, disorders, positive attributes and weapon proficiency levels (including type). They do not gain the Guest's abilities or impairments.

The host may choose to keep their name or take up the Guest's

Guest Reminder

The Guest is the survivor that had the Sleeping Virus Flower in their gear grid when they died.

Ways to Trigger.

is a story event in the Kingdom Death: Monster Core Game rule book.

Event Text.
All at once and without warning, the collected sum of the settlement's lanterns go black. The settlement is plunged into darkness.

Life at the Bottom.
The survivors' victory over the Watcher is a meaningless event in the teeming world around them.

The settlement's conviction is shaken. Lose the Ultimate Weapon or Final Fighting Art.

How can something so insignificant continue to survive? Unless, a greater purpose beyond death awaits. The settlement discovers a way to come and innovates Destiny.

Continue to Life in the Darkness.

Life in the Darkness.
The Watcher's tangled lantern mass is extinguished. Archive the Lantern Hoard settlement location and gain the Exhausted Lantern Hoard settlement location. (The settlement can no longer innovate.)

The darkness closes in as the survivors gather around the fading lights of the Watcher. Tangled in sinews, a final lantern remains. The light within pulses and swirls with desperate energy.

The settlement tears the strange new lantern from the corpse and gains the Final Lantern rare gear. Anyone that holds it bristles with energy. Visions of wisdom and coursing vigor jolt from the lantern through the survivor.

The settlement quickly discovers they can use the Final Lantern to repair broken ones. Gain 3 Survivor's Lantern gear cards.

Continue to the Final Knowledge.

The Final Knowledge.
The Final Lantern glistens with nervous energy. The settlement commences Lantern Research.

The People of the Stars campaign adds story event to Lantern year 5.

Event Text.
Weakness is the anathema to strength.

The Tyrant descends the obsidian staircase with a gift. It places the gift at the settlement's center, and heat washes over the cold stone ground for the first time. The settlement gains the Radiating Orb innovation.

The Tyrant beckons each survivor into the light. The gathered survivors Marvel at Their Reflection in the gleaming obsidian.

Marvel at Their Reflection.
Count the number of survivors in the settlement that have at least 1 Dragon Trait.

3 or less - a pale reflection
The Tyrant gazes bitterly at the pale, anemic limbs crowding into the warmth of the radiant Orb, their chilled goose-flesh resembling nothing of the proud people he imagined they would be. Roll 1d10.

4 or more - a flickering reflection
Among the survivors' dim reflections in the polished black stone of the settlement, the ghosts of the dragons appear to walk among the settlement. Roll 1d10.

There was once a monster that was to lead its master's regal procession. First the monster came as a herald, then its hungry masters. So fierce were the monster's masters that it never thought to protect its own back, knowing what horrors lay behind it.

Level 1+

The sun's mouth opens, creating a deafening drone, and begins to power vomit water directly into the sacred pool. The survivors recognize the gift and cheer as the mineral and bacteria-infused liquid gushes out, its surface casting colorful reflections off of lanterns around the settlement.

roll 1d10

6x resources

is a story event in the Dragon King Expansion rule book.

The People of the Stars campaign adds story event to Lantern year 20.

The People of the Stars settlement sheet incorrectly refers to this story event as "The Dragon Tomb".

Event Text.
The Tyrant's voice booms from the throne, cracking the glassy ground below. It delivers a final edict.

"Erect a fearsome tomb to celebrate my death. When the deed is done, you will lay me in it."

Before their eyes, the Tyrant grows enormous, hideously twisting and tearing itself into its true form.

A mountain of shining, black muscle and a delicate glowing membrane lays curled around its throne, rhythmically undulating with weary breath.

The survivors slowly stir from their slack-jawed horror, clumsily starting to clear the outskirts of the settlement for the tomb's foundation.

Add Tomb: Part 1 to the next year on the timeline.

If the settlement's population has more normal survivors than People of the Stars, the settlement gains the Ultimate Weapon innovation.

If the settlement's population has more People of the Stars than normal survivors, the settlement gains the Final Fighting Art innovation.

Part 1.
The settlement begins the Tomb's foundation. This lantern year, archive all basic resources brought back by returning survivors (rounded down). Gain 1 Hazmat Shield rare gear. If there are fewer than 4 People of the Stars in the settlement, the settlement sacrifices 2 survivors without constellations (if possible). The departing survivors gain +1 luck token. Add Tomb: Part 2 to the next year on the timeline.

Part 2.
The construction is demanding. This lantern year, archive all basic resources brought back by returning survivors (rounded down). If there are fewer than 4 People of the Stars in the settlement, -4 . The departing survivors gain +1 luck token. Add Tomb: Part 3 to the next year on the timeline. 

Returning survivors roll 1d10.

Part 3.
Overwork and lack of rest take their toll. This lantern year, archive all basic resources brought back by returning survivors (rounded down). If there are fewer than 4 People of the Stars in the settlement, any survivors with 0 Hunt XP die.

The departing survivors hide, avoiding labor. They heal all broken severe injuries and gain +2 luck tokens. Add Tomb: Part 4 to the next year on the timeline. 

Part 4.
Doomsday approaches. The settlement feels the languid gaze of God searching their innermost resolve. The departing survivors gain +2 luck tokens.

Event Text.
Dark spots spread across the lantern hoard. A nervous hush falls over the settlement. Slowly, the most daring survivors peer past the darkened lanterns, venturing beneath them in a vast chamber, unknown and undreamed of. Slumbering in the center of the chamber, the survivors can feel a presence of immense danger. Their ultimate predator would soon wake, extinguishing the lantern light that holds the endless darkness at bay.

Starting with this settlement phase, the survivors may awaken and face the sleeping menace. You may move Nemesis Encounter - Watcher to the current lantern year. You cannot move it to a year that already has a Nemesis Encounter on the timeline.
